article:
Green Party of California

The Green Party of California is a state-level political party in the United States formed in 1990. The party is affiliated with the Green Party of the United States and is part of the global Green movement. The party's platform is based on the Ten Key Values of the Green Party, which include grassroots democracy, social justice, ecological wisdom, nonviolence, decentralization, community-based economics, feminism, respect for diversity, personal and global responsibility, and future focus.

# History

## Qualifying for elections

The Green Party of California qualified for the ballot in 1992, after submitting over 100,000 signatures to the Secretary of State. This allowed the party to participate in the 1992 elections, including the presidential election. Ross Perot's candidacy in the 1992 presidential election drew attention away from the Green Party's nominee, but the party still managed to secure over 1% of the vote in the state.

## Electoral milestones

The Green Party of California has had several electoral milestones over the years. In 2000, the party's nominee for U.S. Senate, Medea Benjamin, won over 3% of the vote. In 2002, the party's nominee for Governor, Peter Camejo, won over 5% of the vote, securing a spot on the ballot for the party in the 2004 elections. In 2006, the party's nominee for Lieutenant Governor, Donna Warren, won over 2% of the vote.

## Top-two primaries

In 2010, California voters approved Proposition 14, which established the top-two primary system. Under this system, the top two candidates in the primary election, regardless of party affiliation, advance to the general election. This has made it more difficult for Green Party candidates to qualify for the general election. However, the party has continued to participate in elections and has had success in local elections.

# Platform

The Green Party of California's platform is based on the Ten Key Values of the Green Party. The party's platform includes planks on social justice, environmental protection, economic democracy, and peace. The party supports a wide range of issues, including single-payer healthcare, free public education, and an end to the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

The party's environmental platform includes support for renewable energy, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and protecting California's natural resources. The party also supports social justice issues, including racial justice, LGBTQ+ rights, and immigrant rights.

# Organization

## Membership

The Green Party of California has a membership-based structure. Members can join the party through the state party's website or through local chapters. The party has a dues-paying membership structure, with membership levels ranging from $10 to $100 per year.

The party has a number of local chapters throughout the state, which are responsible for organizing local campaigns and events. The party also has a number of caucuses, including the Lavender Green Caucus, the Latino Green Caucus, and the Disability Rights Caucus.

# Current elected officials

## Mayoral offices

The Green Party of California has a number of elected officials at the local level. One of the party's most notable elected officials is Gayle McLaughlin, who was elected mayor of Richmond in 2006 and re-elected in 2010. McLaughlin was a key figure in the city's efforts to reduce crime and improve public safety.

## Municipal councils

The party has a number of elected officials on municipal councils throughout the state. One of the party's most notable elected officials is Jesse Arreguin, who was elected to the Berkeley City Council in 2008 and re-elected in 2012. Arreguin was a key figure in the city's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable development.

# Election results

## Presidential

The Green Party of California has participated in every presidential election since 1992. The party's nominees have included Ross Perot, Ralph Nader, and Jill Stein.

* 1992: Ross Perot - 1.1% of the vote
* 1996: Ralph Nader - 2.1% of the vote
* 2000: Ralph Nader - 3.8% of the vote
* 2004: David Cobb - 1.3% of the vote
* 2008: Cynthia McKinney - 0.6% of the vote
* 2012: Jill Stein - 0.6% of the vote
* 2016: Jill Stein - 1.4% of the vote

## Gubernatorial

The Green Party of California has participated in every gubernatorial election since 1994. The party's nominees have included Margaret Garcia, Dan Hamburg, and Laura Wells.

* 1994: Margaret Garcia - 1.4% of the vote
* 1998: Dan Hamburg - 1.7% of the vote
* 2002: Peter Camejo - 5.3% of the vote
* 2006: Peter Camejo - 2.3% of the vote
* 2010: Laura Wells - 1.2% of the vote
* 2014: Luis Rodriguez - 1.4% of the vote
* 2018: Josh Jones - 1.2% of the vote

## Election qualifying

The Green Party of California has qualified for the ballot in every election since 1992. The party has submitted over 100,000 signatures to the Secretary of State to qualify for the ballot.

# Notable members

The Green Party of California has a number of notable members, including:

* Medea Benjamin, co-founder of Code Pink and nominee for U.S. Senate in 2000
* Peter Camejo, nominee for Governor in 2002 and 2006
* Laura Wells, nominee for Governor in 2010
* Gayle McLaughlin, mayor of Richmond from 2006 to 2014
* Jesse Arreguin, member of the Berkeley City Council from 2008 to 2016

# See also

* Green Party of the United States
* California Democratic Party
* California Republican Party
* Libertarian Party of California

# Notes

This article is a factual summary of the Green Party of California. The party's platform and positions are subject to change, and this article may not reflect the party's current views.

Adipurush

Adipurush is an upcoming Indian Hindu mythological epic film directed by Om Raut and produced by Bhushan Kumar, Krishan Kumar, Om Raut, Prasad Sutar, and Rajesh Nair. The film is a retelling of the Hindu epic Ramayana, with a focus on the character of Lord Hanuman. The film features a star-studded cast, including Prabhas, Kriti Sanon, and Saif Ali Khan.

# Plot

Adipurush is a modern retelling of the Hindu epic Ramayana, with a focus on the character of Lord Hanuman. The film follows the story of Lord Rama, who is tasked with defeating the demon king Ravana and saving his wife Sita. Along the way, he is aided by Lord Hanuman, a devotee of Lord Rama and a powerful warrior. The film explores the themes of duty, loyalty, and devotion, and features a range of characters from Hindu mythology.

# Cast

The film features a star-studded cast, including:

* Prabhas as Lord Rama
* Kriti Sanon as Sita
* Saif Ali Khan as Ravana
* Sunny Singh as Lakshmana
* Devdatta Nage as Hanuman
* Vatsal Sheth as Shatrughna

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in 2019, with Om Raut set to direct and Bhushan Kumar producing. The film was initially titled "Adipurush", but was later changed to "Ramayana" before being changed back to its original title.

## Casting

The cast was announced in 2020, with Prabhas, Kriti Sanon, and Saif Ali Khan all signing on to star in the film. The cast underwent extensive training and preparation for their roles, including physical training and workshops on Hindu mythology.

## Filming

Filming for the movie began in February 2021 and was completed in November 2021. The film was shot on location in India and the United Arab Emirates, with a team of over 1,000 crew members working on the production.

# Music

The music for the film was composed by Ajay-Atul, with lyrics by Irshad Kamil. The soundtrack features a range of songs, including devotional hymns and epic battle themes.

# Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was launched in 2022, with a series of posters and teasers released on social media. The campaign generated significant buzz and excitement among fans, with many praising the film's visuals and action sequences.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film is scheduled for release on January 12, 2023, in Hindi, Telugu, Tamil, Malayalam, and Kannada.

## Home media

The film will be available to stream on Amazon Prime Video after its theatrical release.

## Game

A video game based on the film was released in 2022, allowing players to take on the role of Lord Hanuman and battle against Ravana's army.

# Reception

## Critical response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its visuals and action sequences while others criticized its storytelling and character development.

## Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹500 crore at the box office.

# Controversies

## Allahabad High Court on Adipurush

In 2022, the Allahabad High Court issued a notice to the film's producers and director, asking them to respond to a petition filed by a local resident who claimed that the film's depiction of Lord Hanuman was "not in line with Hindu mythology".

## Reactions after the teaser release

After the film's teaser was released, many fans took to social media to express their disappointment and outrage over the film's depiction of Lord Hanuman and other Hindu deities.

## Reactions on the film's posters

The film's posters were also criticized for their depiction of Lord Hanuman, with many fans accusing the filmmakers of "distorting" Hindu mythology.

## Dialogues of Adipurush

The film's dialogues were also criticized for being "insensitive" and "disrespectful" to Hindu mythology.

## Backtracking and making contradictory statements

The film's director, Om Raut, faced criticism for backtracking and making contradictory statements about the film's depiction of Lord Hanuman and other Hindu deities.

## Claiming that Lord Hanuman is 'not a god'

Om Raut faced widespread criticism for claiming that Lord Hanuman is "not a god", with many accusing him of being "ignorant" and "disrespectful" to Hindu mythology.

## Ban in Nepal

The film was banned in Nepal after a local court ruled that it was "insensitive" and "disrespectful" to Hindu mythology.

## FIR

An FIR was filed against the film's director and producers in 2022, accusing them of "hurting religious sentiments" and "distorting Hindu mythology".

# See also

* Ramayana
* Hindu mythology
* Lord Hanuman

# Notes

* This article is based on available information and may not be comprehensive or up-to-date.

# External links

* Adipurush on IMDb

Arched Harp
================

The arched harp is a type of harp that features a distinctive arched or curved shape, typically with a rounded or pointed top and a narrower bottom. It is one of the oldest known forms of harp and has been depicted in ancient artwork and literature from various cultures around the world.

Description
-----------

The arched harp is characterized by its curved or bowed shape, which provides additional string tension and allows for a wider range of tonal expression. The instrument typically consists of a wooden or bamboo frame, a set of strings, and a mechanism for tuning and playing the strings. The arched shape of the harp allows for a more efficient use of space, making it a popular choice for traveling musicians and nomadic cultures.

Classification
--------------

The arched harp is a member of the harp family, which is a subset of the larger category of stringed instruments. Harps are characterized by their use of strings stretched between a frame, and are typically played by plucking or strumming the strings with the fingers or a plectrum.

Structure
----------

The arched harp typically consists of the following components:

* Frame: The frame of the arched harp is typically made from wood or bamboo, and is curved or bowed to provide additional string tension.
* Strings: The strings of the arched harp are typically made from animal gut, plant fibers, or metal wire, and are stretched between the frame and a set of tuning pegs.
* Tuning pegs: The tuning pegs are used to tighten or loosen the strings, allowing the player to adjust the pitch and tone of the instrument.
* Soundbox: Some arched harps feature a soundbox or resonator, which helps to amplify and project the sound of the instrument.

Variations
------------

There are many variations of the arched harp, each with its own unique characteristics and features. Some common variations include:

* Size: Arched harps can range in size from small, portable instruments to large, concert-harp-sized instruments.
* Shape: The shape of the arched harp can vary, with some instruments featuring a more rounded or pointed top, and others featuring a more angular or asymmetrical shape.
* Materials: Arched harps can be made from a variety of materials, including wood, bamboo, metal, and stone.
* Decoration: Arched harps are often decorated with intricate carvings, inlays, or other forms of ornamentation.

History
-------

The arched harp has a long and rich history, with depictions of the instrument appearing in ancient artwork and literature from around the world.

Earliest Harp Image
-------------------

The earliest known image of a harp is found on a ancient Sumerian artifact from the city of Ur, which dates back to around 2600 BCE. The image depicts a harp-like instrument with a curved or bowed shape, and is considered one of the earliest known examples of a stringed instrument.

Another Early Image
-------------------

Another early image of a harp is found on an ancient Egyptian artifact from the tomb of Queen Nefertari, which dates back to around 1250 BCE. The image depicts a harp-like instrument with a more angular or asymmetrical shape, and is considered one of the earliest known examples of a harp in ancient Egypt.

Distribution
------------

The arched harp has been found in many cultures around the world, including Mesopotamia, India, China, Egypt, Greece, and Rome.

Mesopotamia
------------

The arched harp was an important instrument in ancient Mesopotamia, where it was depicted in artwork and literature from the Sumerian, Akkadian, and Babylonian civilizations.

India, Indochina
-----------------

The arched harp was also found in ancient India and Indochina, where it was depicted in Hindu and Buddhist artwork and literature.

### Spread of the Arched Harp from India

The arched harp is believed to have spread from India to other parts of Asia, including China, Japan, and Southeast Asia.

### Nuristan

The arched harp was also found in the ancient region of Nuristan, which is located in modern-day Afghanistan and Pakistan.

### Southeast Asia, Burma

The arched harp was an important instrument in ancient Burma, where it was depicted in artwork and literature from the Pagan and Mandalay periods.

### Southeast Asia, Cambodia

The arched harp was also found in ancient Cambodia, where it was depicted in artwork and literature from the Angkor Wat period.

### Karen Harp

The Karen people of Burma and Thailand have a long tradition of playing the arched harp, which is an important part of their cultural heritage.

China

The arched harp was also found in ancient China, where it was depicted in artwork and literature from the Shang and Zhou dynasties.

Egypt
------

The arched harp was an important instrument in ancient Egypt, where it was depicted in artwork and literature from the Old Kingdom to the Roman period.

### Egypt Gallery

A gallery of images depicting arched harps from ancient Egypt can be found in the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

### Egyptian Hieroglyphs

The arched harp is also depicted in Egyptian hieroglyphs, which provide valuable information about the instrument's history and cultural significance.

-----------------

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
==========================

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770–1831) was a German philosopher and one of the most important figures in the history of philosophy. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest philosophers of all time, and his philosophical system has had a profound impact on the development of modern thought. His ideas have influenced fields such as politics, art, literature, and theology, and continue to be studied and debated by scholars and philosophers around the world.

Life
====

### Formative years

#### Stuttgart, Tübingen, Berne, Frankfurt (1770–1800)

Hegel was born on August 27, 1770, in Stuttgart, Germany, to Georg Ludwig Hegel, a secretary to the Duke of Württemberg, and Maria Magdalena Fromm. He was the eldest of three children, and his family was part of the Protestant middle class. Hegel's early education took place at the Stuttgart Gymnasium, where he excelled in his studies, particularly in classical languages and literature.

In 1788, Hegel began his studies at the University of Tübingen, where he was heavily influenced by the ideas of the Enlightenment and the French Revolution. He studied theology, philosophy, and classical languages, and was particularly drawn to the works of Immanuel Kant. During his time at Tübingen, Hegel became friends with other notable thinkers, including Schelling and Hölderlin.

After completing his studies at Tübingen, Hegel worked as a tutor in Berne and Frankfurt, where he continued to develop his philosophical ideas. In 1801, he moved to Jena, where he became a lecturer at the University of Jena.

### Career years

#### Jena, Bamberg, Nuremberg (1801–1816)

During his time at Jena, Hegel developed his philosophical system and published several important works, including "The Phenomenology of Spirit" (1807) and "The Science of Logic" (1812–1816). He also became friends with other notable thinkers, including Goethe and Schiller.

In 1807, Hegel became the rector of a Gymnasium in Bamberg, where he remained for several years. During this time, he continued to develop his philosophical ideas and published several articles and reviews.

In 1816, Hegel became a professor of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg, where he remained for several years. During this time, he published several important works, including "The Philosophy of Right" (1820) and "The Lectures on the Philosophy of History" (1822–1831).

#### Heidelberg, Berlin (1816–1831)

In 1818, Hegel became a professor of philosophy at the University of Berlin, where he remained until his death in 1831. During this time, he published several important works, including "The Philosophy of Nature" (1830) and "The Lectures on the Philosophy of Art" (1820–1829).

Hegel's time at Berlin was marked by controversy and criticism. He was attacked by both conservative and liberal thinkers, who saw his ideas as too radical or too conservative. Despite these challenges, Hegel remained a dominant figure in German philosophy and continued to develop his philosophical system.

Influences
==========

Hegel's philosophical system was influenced by a wide range of thinkers and ideas, including Immanuel Kant, Aristotle, and the French Revolution. He was also influenced by the ideas of his contemporaries, including Schelling and Hölderlin.

The Phenomenology of Spirit
==========================

"The Phenomenology of Spirit" (1807) is one of Hegel's most important works and a central text in his philosophical system. The work is a systematic and dialectical account of the development of consciousness and spirit, from the lowest levels of sensory awareness to the highest levels of philosophical understanding.

Philosophical system
==================

Hegel's philosophical system is a comprehensive and systematic account of reality, knowledge, and spirit. The system is based on a dialectical approach, which sees reality as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

### Science of Logic

"The Science of Logic" (1812–1816) is a central text in Hegel's philosophical system and a systematic account of the laws and structures of thought and reality. The work is a comprehensive and dialectical account of the development of logic, from the lowest levels of abstract thinking to the highest levels of philosophical understanding.

### Philosophy of the real

Hegel's philosophy of the real is a comprehensive and systematic account of reality, knowledge, and spirit. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees reality as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

### The Philosophy of Nature

"The Philosophy of Nature" (1830) is a central text in Hegel's philosophical system and a systematic account of the natural world and the laws and structures of physical reality. The work is a comprehensive and dialectical account of the development of the natural world, from the lowest levels of matter and energy to the highest levels of life and consciousness.

### The Philosophy of Spirit

"The Philosophy of Spirit" is a central text in Hegel's philosophical system and a systematic account of the development of consciousness and spirit, from the lowest levels of sensory awareness to the highest levels of philosophical understanding.

#### Subjective spirit

Hegel's philosophy of subjective spirit is a comprehensive and systematic account of the development of consciousness and the subjective experience of reality. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees the subjective experience as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

#### Objective spirit

Hegel's philosophy of objective spirit is a comprehensive and systematic account of the development of social and cultural reality, from the lowest levels of individual consciousness to the highest levels of collective understanding and being. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees the objective reality as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

#### Absolute spirit

Hegel's philosophy of absolute spirit is a comprehensive and systematic account of the highest levels of philosophical understanding and being, which sees reality as a unified and dialectical whole. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees reality as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

Philosophy of art
================

Hegel's philosophy of art is a comprehensive and systematic account of the nature and significance of art, from the lowest levels of sensory experience to the highest levels of philosophical understanding. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees art as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

Christianity
=============

Hegel's philosophy of Christianity is a comprehensive and systematic account of the nature and significance of Christianity, from the lowest levels of individual consciousness to the highest levels of collective understanding and being. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees Christianity as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

### Early Romantic writings

Hegel's early Romantic writings are a collection of essays and reviews that explore the nature and significance of art, literature, and music. The writings are characterized by a sense of wonder and awe, and a deep appreciation for the creative and imaginative powers of the human spirit.

### The Phenomenology of Spirit

"The Phenomenology of Spirit" (1807) is a central text in Hegel's philosophical system and a systematic account of the development of consciousness and spirit, from the lowest levels of sensory awareness to the highest levels of philosophical understanding. The work is a comprehensive and dialectical account of the development of consciousness and spirit, and explores the nature and significance of Christianity in the context of the emergence of modernity.

### The Berlin lectures

Hegel's Berlin lectures are a collection of lectures that explore the nature and significance of Christianity, from the lowest levels of individual consciousness to the highest levels of collective understanding and being. The lectures are characterized by a sense of depth and complexity, and a deep appreciation for the historical and cultural significance of Christianity.

### Issues of interpretation

Hegel's philosophy of Christianity is characterized by a number of issues of interpretation, including the nature and significance of the Trinity, the relationship between faith and reason, and the role of the Church in the modern world. These issues are the subject of ongoing debate and discussion among scholars and philosophers.

Philosophy of history
===================

Hegel's philosophy of history is a comprehensive and systematic account of the nature and significance of historical events and processes, from the lowest levels of individual consciousness to the highest levels of collective understanding and being. The philosophy is based on a dialectical approach, which sees history as a process of development and transformation, driven by the conflict between opposing forces and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

Dialectics, speculation, idealism
================================

Hegel's philosophy is characterized by a number of key concepts, including dialectics, speculation, and idealism. These concepts are central to his philosophical system, and are the subject of ongoing debate and discussion among scholars and philosophers.

### Thesis–antithesis–synthesis

The thesis–antithesis–synthesis is a central concept in Hegel's philosophical system, and is a key aspect of his dialectical approach. The concept refers to the process of development and transformation that occurs through the conflict between opposing forces, and the emergence of higher levels of understanding and being.

Reception
=========

Hegel's philosophy has had a profound impact on the development of modern thought, and has been the subject of ongoing debate and discussion among scholars and philosophers. The reception of his philosophy has been characterized by a number of different approaches and interpretations, including "Right" and "Left" Hegelianism, and American pragmatism.

### "Right" vs. "Left" Hegelianism

The distinction between "Right" and "Left" Hegelianism refers to the different approaches and interpretations of Hegel's philosophy that emerged in the 19th century. "Right" Hegelianism emphasizes the conservative and traditional aspects of Hegel's philosophy, while "Left" Hegelianism emphasizes the radical and revolutionary aspects.

### Reception in France

Hegel's philosophy has had a significant impact on French thought, and has been the subject of ongoing debate and discussion among French scholars and philosophers. The reception of his philosophy in France has been characterized by a number of different approaches and interpretations, including existentialism and phenomenology.

### American pragmatism

article:
2022 Annexation Referendums in Russian-Occupied Ukraine

The 2022 annexation referendums in Russian-occupied Ukraine were a series of votes held in September 2022 in the eastern and southern regions of Ukraine, which were under the control of Russian forces. The referendums were organized by the Russian-backed authorities in the occupied territories, with the aim of annexing these regions to Russia. The votes were widely condemned by Ukraine and the international community, who considered them to be illegitimate and a violation of Ukraine's sovereignty.

# Background

The idea of holding referendums in the occupied territories of Ukraine was first proposed by the Russian-backed separatist leaders in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions in 2021. The proposal was initially met with skepticism by the Russian authorities, but gained momentum in 2022, following the launch of Russia's large-scale invasion of Ukraine in February.

The Russian government claimed that the referendums were necessary to allow the people of the occupied territories to express their will and determine their future. However, Ukraine and the international community argued that the votes were a sham, designed to legitimize Russia's annexation of Ukrainian territory.

# Organization

The organization of the referendums was overseen by the Russian-backed authorities in the occupied territories, with the assistance of Russian officials. The votes were held in four regions: Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia.

The referendums were organized in a rushed manner, with little time for campaigning or debate. The questions to be put to the voters were not made public until the eve of the vote, and the voting process was shrouded in secrecy.

# Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts

## Questions

The question put to voters in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions was: "Do you support the entry of the Donetsk People's Republic/Zaporizhzhia Oblast into the Russian Federation as a federal subject?"

## Results

According to the official results, 99.23% of voters in the Donetsk region and 98.42% of voters in the Luhansk region supported the annexation of their regions to Russia. The turnout was reported to be 97.51% in Donetsk and 92.6% in Luhansk.

# Kherson Oblast

## Question

The question put to voters in the Kherson region was: "Do you support the entry of the Kherson Oblast into the Russian Federation as a federal subject?"

## Result

According to the official results, 87.05% of voters in the Kherson region supported the annexation of their region to Russia. The turnout was reported to be 78.86%.

# Zaporizhzhia Oblast

## Question

The question put to voters in the Zaporizhzhia region was: "Do you support the entry of the Zaporizhzhia Oblast into the Russian Federation as a federal subject?"

## Result

According to the official results, 93.11% of voters in the Zaporizhzhia region supported the annexation of their region to Russia. The turnout was reported to be 85.38%.

# Other planned locations

## Mykolaiv Oblast

The Russian-backed authorities in the Mykolaiv region had planned to hold a referendum on annexation, but the vote was postponed due to the ongoing fighting in the region.

## Kharkiv Oblast

The Russian-backed authorities in the Kharkiv region had also planned to hold a referendum on annexation, but the vote was cancelled due to the Ukrainian military's advances in the region.

# Opinion polls

There were no independent opinion polls conducted in the occupied territories to gauge public opinion on the annexation referendums. However, polls conducted in Ukraine and among Ukrainian refugees suggested that a majority of Ukrainians opposed the annexation of their country's territory by Russia.

# Opinions on the goals of holding referendums

The Ukrainian government and many international observers believed that the referendums were a pretext for Russia to annex Ukrainian territory and legitimize its occupation. The Russian government claimed that the referendums were necessary to allow the people of the occupied territories to express their will and determine their future.

# Conduct

## First day

The referendums began on September 23, with voters in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions casting their ballots. The voting process was peaceful, but there were reports of irregularities and intimidation of voters.

## Second day

On the second day of voting, September 24, voters in the Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions cast their ballots. The voting process was again peaceful, but there were reports of irregularities and intimidation of voters.

## Third day

On the third day of voting, September 25, voters in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions continued to cast their ballots. The voting process was peaceful, but there were reports of irregularities and intimidation of voters.

## Fourth day

On the fourth day of voting, September 26, voters in the Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions continued to cast their ballots. The voting process was peaceful, but there were reports of irregularities and intimidation of voters.

## Fifth day

On the fifth and final day of voting, September 27, voters in all four regions cast their ballots. The voting process was peaceful, but there were reports of irregularities and intimidation of voters.

# Reactions

## Ukraine

The Ukrainian government condemned the referendums, calling them a "sham" and a "violation of international law." Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said that the referendums were a "pretext for Russia to annex Ukrainian territory."

## Russia

The Russian government welcomed the results of the referendums, saying that they reflected the will of the people in the occupied territories. Russia's President Vladimir Putin said that the referendums were a "democratic expression of the people's will."

## International organisations

The United Nations, the European Union, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) all condemned the referendums, saying that they were illegitimate and a violation of Ukraine's sovereignty.

## Countries

Many countries, including the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom, condemned the referendums and refused to recognize the results. China and India were among the few countries that did not condemn the referendums.

## Human rights organizations

Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International condemned the referendums, saying that they were a "sham" and a "violation of human rights."

## Other

The referendums were also condemned by many other organizations and individuals, including the Ukrainian diaspora and human rights activists.

# Possible consequences

The annexation of Ukrainian territory by Russia could have significant consequences for the region and the world. It could lead to further instability and conflict in Ukraine, and could also have implications for the global economy and international relations.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the referendums saw a significant escalation of the conflict in Ukraine, with both sides suffering heavy losses. The international community continued to condemn Russia's actions, and many countries imposed sanctions on Russia in response to the annexation.

article:
Humza Yousaf

Humza Yousaf is a Scottish politician who has been serving as the First Minister of Scotland since March 2023. A member of the Scottish National Party (SNP), he has been a Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) since 2011. Yousaf has held various ministerial positions, including Cabinet Secretary for Justice and Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care, before becoming the leader of the SNP and the First Minister of Scotland.

#Early life and education

Humza Yousaf was born on April 7, 1985, in Glasgow, Scotland. His parents, Muhammad Yousaf and Shadia Yousaf, are of Pakistani descent. Yousaf's family moved to Glasgow when he was a young child, and he grew up in the city's Pollokshields area. He attended Holyrood Secondary School and later studied Politics at the University of Glasgow, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 2007.

#Early career and political involvement

Before entering politics, Yousaf worked as a parliamentary assistant to Bashir Ahmad, the first Muslim MSP, and later as a researcher for the SNP. He was also involved in various community organizations, including the Glasgow-based charity, the Scottish Islamic Foundation. Yousaf joined the SNP at the age of 16 and quickly became involved in the party's youth wing, the Young Scots for Independence.

#Early parliamentary career

##Election to Holyrood

Yousaf was first elected to the Scottish Parliament in 2011, representing the Glasgow region. At the time of his election, he was the youngest MSP in the Scottish Parliament.

##Junior ministerial career (2012–2018)

In 2012, Yousaf was appointed as the Minister for External Affairs and International Development, a junior ministerial position. In this role, he was responsible for promoting Scotland's interests abroad and overseeing the country's international development policy. In 2014, he was appointed as the Minister for Europe and International Development, with additional responsibilities for European affairs.

##Cabinet Secretary for Justice (2018–2021)

In 2018, Yousaf was appointed as the Cabinet Secretary for Justice, a senior ministerial position. In this role, he was responsible for overseeing the justice system in Scotland, including the police, courts, and prisons.

###Hate Crime Bill

During his tenure as Justice Secretary, Yousaf introduced the Hate Crime Bill, which aimed to strengthen laws against hate crime in Scotland. The bill, which was passed in 2020, created a new offense of "stirring up hatred" and increased penalties for hate crimes.

##Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care (2021–2023)

In 2021, Yousaf was appointed as the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care, replacing Jeane Freeman. In this role, he was responsible for overseeing the National Health Service (NHS) in Scotland and developing policy on health and social care.

###COVID-19 pandemic

During the COVID-19 pandemic, Yousaf played a key role in the Scottish Government's response to the crisis. He worked closely with NHS Scotland and other stakeholders to develop and implement policies to mitigate the spread of the virus and protect public health.

###NHS waiting times

Yousaf also focused on reducing NHS waiting times, which had become a major issue in Scotland. He introduced a number of initiatives aimed at improving patient flow and reducing delays, including the creation of a new waiting times improvement plan.

##2023 SNP leadership election

In March 2023, Yousaf announced his candidacy for the leadership of the SNP, following the resignation of Nicola Sturgeon. He won the election on March 27, 2023, defeating Kate Forbes and Ash Regan.

#First Minister of Scotland

##Domestic policy

As First Minister, Yousaf has focused on a range of domestic policy issues, including the economy, education, and health. He has committed to increasing investment in public services and reducing poverty and inequality.

##Economic policy

Yousaf has also emphasized the need for a strong and sustainable economy in Scotland. He has committed to supporting businesses and promoting economic growth, while also addressing the challenges posed by Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic.

##Drugs policy

Yousaf has taken a progressive approach to drugs policy, advocating for the decriminalization of possession and the introduction of safe consumption rooms. He has also committed to increasing funding for addiction services and supporting those affected by addiction.

##Education policy

Yousaf has emphasized the importance of education in Scotland, committing to increasing funding for schools and improving educational outcomes. He has also pledged to address the attainment gap and support disadvantaged pupils.

##Hate crime policy

Yousaf has continued to prioritize hate crime policy, building on the work he undertook as Justice Secretary. He has committed to increasing funding for hate crime prevention and support services, and to promoting a culture of tolerance and respect in Scotland.

##Programme for government

Yousaf's first Programme for Government, published in September 2023, set out his priorities for the Scottish Government. The programme included a range of commitments on issues such as the economy, education, and health, as well as a focus on addressing the climate emergency and promoting social justice.

##International affairs

###European Union

Yousaf has been a strong supporter of Scotland's membership of the European Union. He has advocated for a second EU referendum and has worked to maintain Scotland's relationships with EU countries.

###Scotland–Pakistan relations

Yousaf has also emphasized the importance of Scotland's relationships with countries such as Pakistan. He has committed to increasing trade and cultural exchange between the two countries, and to promoting people-to-people diplomacy.

###Ukraine invasion

Yousaf has condemned the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and has committed to supporting the Ukrainian people. He has worked with the UK Government and other international partners to provide humanitarian aid and support.

###Israel–Hamas war

Yousaf has also spoken out on the conflict in the Middle East, condemning the use of violence and advocating for a peaceful resolution. He has committed to supporting the Palestinian people and to promoting a two-state solution.

##Resignation

Yousaf has not resigned as First Minister. He remains in office and continues to lead the Scottish Government.

#Political positions

Yousaf is a member of the Scottish National Party and has been a strong advocate for Scottish independence. He has also been a vocal supporter of progressive policies on issues such as climate change, social justice, and human rights.

#Parliamentary electoral history

##2021

Yousaf was re-elected as the MSP for Glasgow Pollok in the 2021 Scottish Parliament election. He received 18,735 votes, a majority of 7,455.

##2016

Yousaf was re-elected as the MSP for Glasgow Pollok in the 2016 Scottish Parliament election. He received 14,394 votes, a majority of 5,820.

#Personal life

Yousaf is married to Nadia El-Nakla, a communications specialist. The couple has a daughter, Amal, born in 2018.

#Honours

Yousaf has received a number of honours and awards for his work, including the Scottish Politician of the Year award in 2019.

article:
2022 AFL Grand Final

The 2022 AFL Grand Final was the 126th edition of the Australian Football League's (AFL) annual Grand Final, the culmination of the 2022 AFL season. The match was played between the Geelong Cats and the Sydney Swans at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) on September 24, 2022. Geelong won the match by a margin of 81 points, claiming their 16th VFL/AFL premiership.

#Background
The 2022 AFL season was marked by the return of a full home-and-away fixture after two seasons affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The season saw the emergence of new contenders, with the Sydney Swans and the Geelong Cats ultimately finishing as the top two teams on the ladder. The Swans, led by coach John Longmire and captain Callum Mills, were seeking their sixth VFL/AFL premiership, while the Cats, led by coach Chris Scott and captain Joel Selwood, were seeking their 16th.

#Ceremonies and entertainment
The pre-match ceremonies and entertainment were an integral part of the 2022 AFL Grand Final.

##Parade
The traditional Grand Final parade was held on the morning of the match, with players from both teams participating in the event. The parade started at the Old Treasury Building and made its way to the MCG, with thousands of fans lining the streets to catch a glimpse of their favorite players.

##On-field events
Prior to the match, the Australian national anthem was performed by Christine Anu. The pre-game entertainment also included a performance by Australian rock band Cold Chisel, who played a selection of their hit songs.

#Match summary
The 2022 AFL Grand Final was played in front of a crowd of 100,024 at the MCG.

##First quarter
The match began with the Geelong Cats kicking the first goal through Tom Hawkins. The Cats dominated the quarter, kicking 6.0 (36) to the Swans' 1.2 (8).

##Second quarter
The Swans fought back in the second quarter, kicking 3.2 (20) to the Cats' 2.2 (14). However, the Cats maintained their lead, going into halftime with a margin of 22 points.

##Third quarter
The Cats extended their lead in the third quarter, kicking 4.4 (28) to the Swans' 2.1 (13). The quarter saw a number of injuries to key players, including the Swans' Lance Franklin and the Cats' Patrick Dangerfield.

##Final quarter
The Cats sealed the match in the final quarter, kicking 5.6 (36) to the Swans' 1.1 (7). The quarter saw the Cats' Isaac Smith kick four goals, including the sealer.

##Overall
The final score was Geelong 20.13 (133) to Sydney 8.4 (52). The Cats' victory marked their 16th VFL/AFL premiership, with the team celebrating on the field and in the locker room.

##Norm Smith Medal
The Norm Smith Medal was awarded to Isaac Smith, who kicked four goals and had 32 disposals for the Cats. Smith's performance was widely praised, with many considering him the best on ground.

article:
James Madison
================

James Madison (March 16, 1751 – June 28, 1836) was an American statesman, diplomat, and Founding Father who served as the fourth President of the United States from 1809 to 1817. He is often referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" for his role in drafting and promoting the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights.

Early life and education
------------------------

James Madison was born in Port Conway, Virginia, to Colonel James Madison Sr. and Nelly Conway Madison. He was the oldest of 12 children, and his family was considered to be of moderate means. Madison received a classical education at Innes Creek School and later attended the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University), where he studied law, philosophy, and politics. After graduating in 1771, Madison returned to Virginia and began to study law, but he never pursued a career in law, instead focusing on politics.

American Revolution and Articles of Confederation
-------------------------------------------------

During the American Revolution, Madison served as a member of the Virginia House of Delegates and later as a delegate to the Continental Congress. In 1784, he was appointed to the Virginia House of Delegates, where he became a leader in the fight for independence from Great Britain. Madison played a key role in the drafting of the Articles of Confederation, the first constitution of the United States, but he was ultimately dissatisfied with the final product.

Ratification of the Constitution
---------------------------------

In 1787, Madison was a key delegate to the Constitutional Convention, where he played a leading role in drafting the United States Constitution. He worked closely with other Founding Fathers, including George Washington and Alexander Hamilton, to create a new form of government that would replace the Articles of Confederation. Madison's contributions to the Constitution were significant, and he is often credited with drafting the document's framework and many of its key provisions.

Congressman and party leader (1789–1801)
------------------------------------------

### Election to Congress

In 1789, Madison was elected to the United States House of Representatives, where he became a leader in the fight for a strong central government. He was a key ally of President George Washington and played a crucial role in the passage of several key pieces of legislation, including the Tariff Act of 1789 and the Jay Treaty.

### Bill of Rights

In 1789, Madison was tasked with drafting a Bill of Rights, a set of amendments to the Constitution that would protect individual liberties. Madison drew heavily on the Virginia Declaration of Rights, which had been drafted by George Mason in 1776. The Bill of Rights was ratified in 1791 and has since become a cornerstone of American law.

### Founding the Democratic–Republican Party

In 1792, Madison, along with Thomas Jefferson, founded the Democratic-Republican Party, which would become a major force in American politics for decades to come. The party was formed in opposition to the Federalist Party, which was led by Alexander Hamilton.

### Marriage and family

In 1794, Madison married Dolley Payne Todd, a wealthy widow who was 17 years his junior. The couple had no children together, but Madison adopted Dolley's son from her previous marriage.

### Adams presidency

During the presidency of John Adams, Madison became increasingly opposed to the Federalist Party's policies, particularly the Alien and Sedition Acts. Madison and Jefferson wrote the Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions, which argued that the states had the right to nullify federal laws that they deemed unconstitutional.

Secretary of State (1801–1809)
------------------------------

In 1801, Madison was appointed Secretary of State by President Thomas Jefferson. During his time in office, Madison played a key role in the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the United States. He also oversaw the Lewis and Clark Expedition, which explored the western territories of the United States.

### 1808 presidential election

In 1808, Madison was elected as the fourth President of the United States, defeating Charles C. Pinckney in the general election.

Presidency (1809–1817)
------------------------

### Inauguration and cabinet

Madison was inaugurated as President on March 4, 1809. He appointed a cabinet that included James Monroe as Secretary of State and Robert Smith as Secretary of the Navy.

### War of 1812

#### Prelude to war

During Madison's presidency, tensions between the United States and Great Britain increased, particularly over issues such as impressment of American sailors and trade restrictions. In 1812, Madison asked Congress to declare war on Great Britain, which they did on June 18, 1812.

#### Military actions

The War of 1812 was fought on several fronts, including land battles in the north and naval battles on the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean. The war was marked by several key American victories, including the Battle of Lake Erie and the Battle of the Thames.

### Postwar period and decline of the Federalist opposition

After the War of 1812, the Federalist Party declined in influence, and the Democratic-Republican Party became the dominant force in American politics. Madison oversaw the signing of the Treaty of Ghent, which ended the war, and he worked to rebuild the American economy.

### Native American policy

During Madison's presidency, he oversaw the forced relocation of several Native American tribes, including the Creek and the Seminole. Madison believed that the Native American tribes should be assimilated into white culture, and he supported the creation of Indian schools and missions.

### Election of 1816

In 1816, Madison declined to run for re-election, and James Monroe was elected as his successor.

Post-presidency (1817–1836)
---------------------------

After leaving office, Madison retired to his estate at Montpelier, where he lived until his death in 1836. During his retirement, Madison remained active in politics and continued to advocate for the causes that he had supported during his presidency.

### Death

James Madison died on June 28, 1836, at the age of 85. He was buried on the grounds of Montpelier, where his wife Dolley was buried several years later.

Political and religious views
-----------------------------

### Federalism

Madison was a strong supporter of federalism, which he believed was essential to the survival of the United States. He believed that a strong central government was necessary to regulate commerce, provide for national defense, and enforce the law.

### Religion

Madison was a member of the Episcopal Church, and he believed in the importance of separating church and state. He supported the principle of religious freedom and opposed the establishment of a national church.

Slavery
--------

Madison owned slaves throughout his life, and he struggled with the moral implications of slavery. In his later years, Madison became increasingly opposed to slavery, and he supported the colonization of freed slaves in Africa.

Legacy
--------

James Madison is remembered as one of the most important figures in American history. He played a key role in the drafting of the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights, and he served as President during the War of 1812. Madison's legacy continues to be felt today, and he remains an important figure in American politics and law.

Mass. and Cass

Mass. and Cass is a area in Boston, Massachusetts, known for its high concentration of social services, including homeless shelters, substance abuse treatment centers, and methadone clinics. The area has been a focal point of concern in recent years due to the growing number of people struggling with homelessness and addiction, and the resulting impact on local businesses and residents.

Aftermath of Long Island closure

The area of Mass. and Cass began to attract attention in 2014, when the City of Boston closed the Long Island shelter and recovery services due to structural concerns with the bridge connecting the island to the mainland. The closure resulted in the relocation of over 700 people to various shelters and services in the city, with many ending up in the area of Mass. and Cass.

Closure of Long Island services

The closure of the Long Island shelter and recovery services was intended to be temporary, but it ultimately became permanent. The city cited the high cost of repairing the bridge and the need to prioritize other infrastructure projects. However, the closure had a significant impact on the people who relied on the services, many of whom were struggling with addiction and homelessness.

Shelter openings at Mass. and Cass

In response to the closure of the Long Island shelter, the city opened several new shelters in the area of Mass. and Cass. These shelters were intended to provide temporary housing and services to those in need, but they quickly became overcrowded and understaffed. The shelters were also criticized for their poor conditions and lack of amenities.

Business concerns

The influx of new shelters and services in the area of Mass. and Cass has been a source of concern for local businesses. Many business owners have reported an increase in crime and disorderly behavior, and some have even gone out of business due to the negative impact on their operations. The city has attempted to address these concerns by increasing police presence and providing additional support services, but the issue remains a contentious one.

Population

The population of Mass. and Cass is diverse and includes people from a wide range of backgrounds. However, the area is disproportionately affected by homelessness and addiction, with many people struggling to access basic services and support. According to city data, the area is home to over 1,000 people who are experiencing homelessness, with many more at risk of becoming homeless.

In recent years, the city has made several attempts to clear out the encampment of homeless people and tents in the area of Mass. and Cass. article:
Anton Webern
================

Anton Webern (1883–1945) was an Austrian composer and conductor who played a pivotal role in the development of atonality and twelve-tone serialism. As a key figure in the Second Viennese School, Webern's music had a profound impact on the course of Western classical music, influencing generations of composers to come.

Biography
==========

### 1883–1908: Upbringing between late Imperial Vienna and countryside

#### Bucolic Heimat

Webern was born on December 3, 1883, in Vienna, Austria, to a family of civil servants. His childhood was marked by frequent moves between Vienna and the countryside, where his family would often spend their summers. This bucolic upbringing would later influence his music, which often reflects a deep connection to nature.

#### University

Webern began his musical studies at the University of Vienna, where he earned a doctorate in musicology in 1906. During his time at university, he was exposed to the works of Richard Wagner and Richard Strauss, which would later influence his compositional style.

#### Schoenberg and his circle

In 1904, Webern met Arnold Schoenberg, who would become his mentor and friend. Schoenberg's innovative and avant-garde compositional style had a profound impact on Webern, who soon became a devoted student of Schoenberg's. Through Schoenberg, Webern was introduced to a circle of like-minded musicians, including Alban Berg and Erwin Stein.

### 1908–1918: Early adulthood in Austria-Hungary and German Empire

#### Marriage

In 1911, Webern married Wilhelmine Mörtl, with whom he would have three children. The couple settled in Mödling, a suburb of Vienna, where Webern would spend much of his life.

#### Early conducting career

Webern began his conducting career in 1908, leading the chorus of the Vienna Singverein. He would go on to conduct various ensembles throughout Austria and Germany, including the Vienna Symphony Orchestra.

#### Psychotherapy

In 1913, Webern underwent psychotherapy with Alfred Adler, a prominent Austrian psychiatrist. This experience would later influence his music, which often explores themes of psychological introspection.

#### "Old song" of "lost paradise"

Webern's early music is characterized by a sense of nostalgia for a lost paradise. This theme is reflected in his song cycle, "Entflieht auf leichten Kähnen" (1908), which sets texts by Stefan George.

#### World War I

During World War I, Webern served in the Austro-Hungarian Army, stationed in Vienna. The war had a profound impact on his music, which became increasingly somber and introspective.

#### Austrian defeat and socioeconomic strain

Following Austria's defeat in the war, the country was plunged into socioeconomic crisis. Webern's music from this period reflects the sense of disorientation and disillusionment that characterized the era.

### 1918–1933: Rise in Rotes Wien (Interwar Vienna)

#### Society for Private Musical Performances

In 1918, Webern co-founded the Society for Private Musical Performances, a organization dedicated to promoting new music. The society would play a key role in promoting Webern's music, as well as that of his contemporaries.

#### Mature conducting career

During the 1920s, Webern's conducting career flourished, with appointments at the Vienna Symphony Orchestra and the German Opera House in Berlin.

#### Relative success in a destabilizing society

Despite the socioeconomic turmoil of the era, Webern's music enjoyed relative success during the 1920s. His music was championed by critics such as Paul Bekker, who recognized Webern's innovative compositional style.

### 1933–1938: Perseverance in Schwarzes Wien (Austrofascist Vienna)

#### Marginalization at home

Following the rise of Austrofascism in Austria, Webern's music was increasingly marginalized. His Jewish heritage and association with Schoenberg, who was Jewish, made him a target for anti-Semitic persecution.

#### Besieged milieu and political confusion

The Austrofascist regime's cultural policies were marked by confusion and inconsistency. Webern's music was occasionally promoted, but more often it was suppressed or marginalized.

#### Visiting conducting career

During the 1930s, Webern's conducting career took him to various cities throughout Europe, including Paris and Amsterdam.

### 1938–1939: Inner emigration in Nazi Germany

#### Anschluss

Following the Anschluss, Austria was annexed by Nazi Germany. Webern's music was immediately banned, and he was forced into inner emigration.

#### Kristallnacht and recoil

The Kristallnacht pogrom in 1938 marked a turning point for Webern, who was deeply shocked by the violence and hatred unleashed against Jewish communities.

### 1939–1945: Hope and disillusionment during World War II

#### Swiss and Reich prospects

During World War II, Webern's music was occasionally performed in Switzerland, which remained neutral throughout the conflict. However, his prospects for a conducting career in Germany were non-existent.

#### Wartime hopes and reality

Webern's music from this period reflects a sense of hope and disillusionment. His String Quartet (1937-1938) is a masterpiece of somber introspection.

#### Refuge and death in Mittersill

In 1945, Webern was accidentally shot and killed by an American soldier in Mittersill, Austria, where he had sought refuge.

Music
=====

Webern's music is characterized by a unique blend of atonality and serialism. His compositional style evolved significantly over the course of his career, reflecting his responses to changing cultural and historical contexts.

### 1899–1908: Formative juvenilia and emergence from study

Webern's early music is marked by a sense of experimentation and discovery. His String Quartet (1905) is a key work from this period, showcasing his emerging compositional style.

### 1908–1914: Atonality and aphorisms

Webern's music from this period is characterized by a sense of fragmentation and dislocation. His Six Pieces for Orchestra (1913) are a masterpiece of atonal innovation.

### 1914–1924: Mid-period Lieder

Webern's Lieder from this period are marked by a sense of introspection and psychological complexity. His settings of texts by Stefan George and Rainer Maria Rilke are particularly notable.

### 1924–1945: Formal coherence and expansion

Webern's music from this period is characterized by a sense of formal coherence and expansion. His String Quartet (1937-1938) is a masterpiece of serialist innovation.

### Arrangements and orchestrations

Webern was a prolific arranger and orchestrator, working on music by Bach, Mozart, and Schubert, among others. His arrangements of Debussy's Preludes are particularly notable.

Reception, influence, and legacy
==================================

Webern's music had a profound impact on the development of Western classical music. His innovative compositional style influenced generations of composers, from Pierre Boulez to Elliott Carter.

### Performance practice

Webern's music is characterized by a sense of complexity and difficulty. His music requires a high degree of technical skill and interpretive insight.

### Contemporaries

Webern's contemporaries included a range of notable composers, including Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Igor Stravinsky.

#### Artists

Webern's music was often championed by artists and intellectuals, including Paul Klee and Wassily Kandinsky.

#### Musicians

Webern's music was performed by a range of notable musicians, including the Vienna Symphony Orchestra and the German Opera House in Berlin.

### 1947–1950s: (Re)discovery and post-Webernism

Following World War II, Webern's music experienced a significant resurgence in popularity. His music was championed by composers such as Pierre Boulez and Karlheinz Stockhausen.

### 1950s onward: Beyond (late) Webern

In the 1950s and 1960s, Webern's music continued to influence a range of composers, from Elliott Carter to György Ligeti.

### Eastern Europe

Webern's music had a significant impact on Eastern European composers, particularly in Poland and Hungary.

#### Eastern Bloc

Webern's music was occasionally performed in the Eastern Bloc, despite the cultural and ideological tensions of the era.

#### Soviet Russia

Webern's music was largely suppressed in Soviet Russia, due to its association with Western modernism and avant-gardism.

### Dance

Webern's music has been used in a range of dance productions, including works by Merce Cunningham and Pina Bausch.

### Since the 1980s: Reappraisals and historiography

In recent years, Webern's music has undergone significant reappraisal and reevaluation. His music is now recognized as a key part of the Western classical tradition.

=====================

Webern made a range of recordings throughout his career, including performances of his own music and music by other composers.

article:
Running Up That Hill
=====================

"Running Up That Hill" is a song by English singer-songwriter Kate Bush, released in 1985 as the lead single from her fifth studio album, Hounds of Love. The song was a major commercial success, reaching the top 10 in several countries, including the UK, where it peaked at number 3 on the Singles Chart.

Music and Lyrics
----------------

"Running Up That Hill" is a synth-pop song with a driving beat and a memorable chorus. The lyrics, written by Bush, are somewhat abstract and open to interpretation. The song's title is inspired by the idea of swapping lives with someone, to see how they feel and to understand their perspective. Bush has said that the song was inspired by a conversation she had with a friend, in which they discussed the idea of switching lives with someone for a day.

The song's lyrics are delivered in a dramatic and emotive style, with Bush's vocals soaring on the chorus. The song's instrumentation is dominated by synthesizers and a drum machine, which gives the song a distinctive 80s sound.

Recording
----------

"Running Up That Hill" was recorded at Bush's home studio, with Bush playing and programming the instruments herself. The song's drum machine pattern was created using a Fairlight CMI, a digital sampler and synthesizer that was widely used in the 1980s.

The song's vocal performance was recorded in a single take, with Bush singing and playing the piano simultaneously. Bush has said that she was experimenting with the idea of "vocal processing" during the recording of the song, using various effects to create a unique sound.

Music Video
------------

The music video for "Running Up That Hill" was directed by Bush and her brother, Paddy Bush. The video features Bush performing the song in a dark and atmospheric setting, with flashing lights and smoke effects.

The video was heavily influenced by the work of German Expressionist filmmakers, such as F.W. Murnau and Fritz Lang. Bush has said that she was inspired by the idea of creating a "mini-film" that would complement the song's lyrics and music.

Release
--------

"Running Up That Hill" was released in August 1985 as the lead single from Hounds of Love. The song was a major commercial success, reaching the top 10 in several countries, including the UK, where it peaked at number 3 on the Singles Chart.

The song's success helped to establish Bush as a major star in the UK and beyond, and it remains one of her most popular and enduring songs.

2012 Olympics Remix
-------------------

In 2012, a remix of "Running Up That Hill" was released as part of the London 2012 Olympics. The remix, which was created by Bush and her longtime collaborator, Del Palmer, was used as the theme music for the Olympics' closing ceremony.

The remix features a new vocal performance from Bush, as well as additional instrumentation and production. The remix was well-received by fans and critics, and it helped to introduce the song to a new generation of listeners.

2022 Revival and Stranger Things
---------------------------------

In 2022, "Running Up That Hill" experienced a major revival in popularity, thanks in part to its use in the Netflix series Stranger Things. The song was featured prominently in the show's fourth season, and it quickly became a viral hit on social media.

The song's revival was fueled by its use in a pivotal scene in the show, in which the character Max Mayfield (played by Sadie Sink) listens to the song on her Walkman. The scene was widely praised by fans and critics, and it helped to introduce the song to a new generation of listeners.

Critical Response
-----------------

"Running Up That Hill" has been widely praised by critics for its innovative production and Bush's powerful vocal performance. The song has been described as a "classic" and a "masterpiece" by numerous critics, and it is widely regarded as one of Bush's best works.

In a 1985 review of the song, Rolling Stone magazine described it as "a stunningly atmospheric and emotionally charged song" that "sets a new standard for Bush's work". The song has since been included on numerous "best of" lists, including Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

Live Performances
-----------------

"Running Up That Hill" has been a staple of Bush's live shows for many years, and it remains one of her most popular songs with fans. Bush has performed the song on numerous tours, including her 1987 The Whole Story tour and her 2014 Before the Dawn tour.

In 2014, Bush performed the song as part of her Before the Dawn tour, which was widely praised by critics and fans. The song was performed in a dramatic and atmospheric setting, with Bush's vocal performance accompanied by a full band and elaborate lighting effects.

Cover Versions
----------------

"Running Up That Hill" has been covered by numerous artists over the years, including Placebo, Within Temptation, and The Futureheads. The song has also been sampled and interpolated by numerous artists, including rapper MF DOOM.

In 2003, the song was covered by Placebo, whose version was included on their album Covers. The song has since been covered by numerous other artists, including Within Temptation and The Futureheads.

Track Listing and Formats
-------------------------

The original single release of "Running Up That Hill" included the following tracks:

* "Running Up That Hill" (5:05)
* "Under the Ivy" (2:09)

The song was later included on Bush's album Hounds of Love, which was released in 1985.

article:
Cirkus (film)

Cirkus is an upcoming Indian Hindi-language period comedy film directed by Rohit Shetty and produced by Reliance Entertainment, T-Series and Rohit Shetty Picturez. The film is an adaptation of William Shakespeare's play The Comedy of Errors, with elements of Indian culture and setting.

# Plot

The film is set in the 1960s and follows the story of two identical twins, both played by Ranveer Singh, who were separated at birth. The twins, one a shy and timid man named Sangram Bhalerao and the other a confident and outgoing man named Ajay Bhalerao, lead separate lives until they coincidentally meet in a small town in India. The twins' lives become intertwined as they get caught up in a series of misadventures and mistaken identities.

As the story unfolds, the twins become embroiled in a complex web of relationships and deceptions, involving a beautiful woman named Bindu (Pooja Hegde), a cunning thief named Rukmini (Jacqueline Fernandez), and a group of bumbling police officers. The film's plot is a classic tale of mistaken identities, love triangles, and comedic misunderstandings, all set against the vibrant backdrop of 1960s India.

# Cast

* Ranveer Singh as Sangram Bhalerao / Ajay Bhalerao
* Pooja Hegde as Bindu
* Jacqueline Fernandez as Rukmini
* Varun Sharma as Dharam Goli
* Siddhartha Jadhav as Banku Bhaiya
* Johnny Lever as IPS Officer
* Sanjay Mishra as Babli Bhaiya
* Vrajesh Hirjee as Guruji
* Mukesh Tiwari as Bhole Shankar
* Anil Charanjeett as Rajeshri Deshpande
* Ashwini Kalsekar as Rajeshri's wife
* Vijay Patkar as Builder
* Sulabha Arya as Dharam's mother
* Brijendra Kala as Ajay's father

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in October 2020, with Rohit Shetty set to direct and Ranveer Singh starring in the lead role. The film is an adaptation of William Shakespeare's play The Comedy of Errors, with elements of Indian culture and setting. The screenplay was written by Yunus Sajawal, Farhad Samji, and Sanchit Bendre.

## Casting

Ranveer Singh was the first actor to be cast in the film, playing the dual role of Sangram and Ajay Bhalerao. Pooja Hegde was cast as Bindu, the love interest of one of the twins, while Jacqueline Fernandez was cast as Rukmini, a cunning thief. Varun Sharma, Siddhartha Jadhav, Johnny Lever, and Sanjay Mishra were cast in supporting roles.

## Filming

Principal photography began in November 2020 and wrapped up in February 2022. The film was shot on location in India, with some scenes filmed in Mumbai and others in Ooty. The film's production team built a large set in Mumbai's Film City to recreate the look and feel of 1960s India.

## Post-production

Post-production work on the film began in March 2022, with the film's editor, Bunty Nagi, working on the final cut. The film's visual effects were handled by a team of artists from Prime Focus, who worked on creating the film's elaborate sets and action sequences.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by Devi Sri Prasad, with lyrics written by Kumaar, Ashish Pandit, and Shabbir Ahmed. The film's score was composed by Amar Mohile. The soundtrack features five original songs, including "Current Laga Re", "Sun Zara", "Aashiqui Aa Gayi", "Cutie Pie", and "Tere Siva".

The 2023 ICC Women's T20 World Cup was the eighth edition of the ICC Women's T20 World Cup, the biennial international Twenty20 cricket championship for women's national teams organized by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament was held in South Africa from February 10 to February 26, 2023.

#Teams and qualification

A total of 12 teams participated in the tournament, including the top 8 teams from the 2020 ICC Women's T20 World Cup, the hosts South Africa, and 3 additional teams that qualified through the 2022 ICC Women's T20 World Cup Qualifier. The 3 teams that qualified through the qualifier were Bangladesh, Ireland, and Sri Lanka.

#Squads

Each team named a squad of 15 players for the tournament. The squads were announced in January 2023. Australia named a strong squad, led by Meg Lanning, while India named a young squad, led by Harmanpreet Kaur. South Africa named a balanced squad, led by Suné Luus, while England named a strong squad, led by Heather Knight.

#Venues

The tournament was held across three venues in South Africa: Newlands Cricket Ground in Cape Town, Boland Park in Paarl, and St George's Park in Gqeberha. Newlands Cricket Ground hosted the final, while Boland Park hosted the semi-finals.

#Match officials

The ICC named a panel of 12 match officials for the tournament, including 6 umpires and 6 match referees. The match officials were from various countries, including Australia, England, India, and South Africa.

#Prize money

The total prize money for the tournament was $1.6 million, with the winners receiving $750,000 and the runners-up receiving $380,000.

#Warm-up matches

The teams played warm-up matches from February 6 to February 8, 2023. Australia played two warm-up matches against India and South Africa, while England played two warm-up matches against West Indies and Bangladesh.

#Group stage

The group stage was played from February 10 to February 21, 2023, with the teams divided into two groups of 6 teams each. Each team played the other teams in their group once, with the top 2 teams from each group advancing to the semi-finals.

#Knockout stage

The knockout stage was played from February 23 to February 26, 2023, with the semi-finals and final played at the Boland Park and Newlands Cricket Ground respectively.

Treat Williams

Richard Treat Williams is a renowned American actor, born on December 1, 1951, in Stamford, Connecticut. With a career spanning over four decades, he has established himself as a talented and versatile actor, excelling in film, television, and theatre. Williams' dedication to his craft has earned him numerous awards and nominations, solidifying his position as a respected figure in the entertainment industry.

#Early life and education

Treat Williams was born to Richard Norman Williams, a corporate executive, and Marion (née Andrews) Williams, a museum curator. He is the youngest of three children, and his family moved frequently during his childhood due to his father's job. Williams developed an interest in acting at a young age and attended the prestigious Franklin D. Roosevelt High School in Hyde Park, New York. After graduating in 1969, he enrolled at the Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, where he studied drama.

#Career

##1972–1979: Stage work and film breakthrough

Williams began his career in the early 1970s, performing in various stage productions, including a touring company of the musical "Grease." In 1975, he made his Broadway debut in the play "Grease," earning a Theatre World Award for his portrayal of Danny Zuko. His breakthrough role came in 1979 when he played the title character in the film "Hair," directed by Miloš Forman. The film's success catapulted Williams to stardom, and he became a household name.

##1980s roles

The 1980s saw Williams appear in a range of films, including "Prince of the City" (1981), "The Pursuit of D.B. Cooper" (1981), and "Smooth Talk" (1985). He also continued to work in theatre, starring in the Broadway productions of "The Most Happy Fella" (1979) and "The Glass Menagerie" (1983). In 1984, Williams received a Golden Globe nomination for his performance in the television film "A Streetcar Named Desire."

##1990s–2006: Film, theatre, and Everwood

In the 1990s, Williams appeared in several films, including "Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead" (1995), "The Phantom" (1996), and "Deep Rising" (1998). He also continued to work in theatre, starring in the Broadway productions of "Fifth of July" (1998) and "The Lion in Winter" (1999). In 2002, Williams began starring in the WB television series "Everwood," playing the lead role of Dr. Andy Brown. The show ran for four seasons, earning Williams a Screen Actors Guild Award nomination for his performance.

##2007–2023: Final years

In the late 2000s, Williams appeared in a range of films, including "What Happens in Vegas" (2008), "127 Hours" (2010), and "In the Blood" (2014). He also continued to work in television, starring in the ABC series " Brothers & Sisters" (2007-2011) and the CW series "Chicago Fire" (2012-2013). In his final years, Williams appeared in several films, including "The Congressman" (2016), "Second Act" (2018), and " Operation Finale" (2018).

#Accolades

Throughout his career, Treat Williams has received numerous awards and nominations for his performances. He has been recognized with a Theatre World Award, a Golden Globe nomination, and a Screen Actors Guild Award nomination. Williams has also been honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

#Personal life

##Addiction issues

2022 NFL Draft

The 2022 NFL Draft was the 87th edition of the National Football League's annual draft, where NFL teams select eligible college football players and other eligible players to join their teams. The draft took place from April 28 to 30, 2022, at the Caesars Forum in Paradise, Nevada.

# Host City

The 2022 NFL Draft was held in Las Vegas, Nevada, marking the first time the city has hosted the event. The draft was originally scheduled to take place in Las Vegas in 2020, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it was postponed and ultimately held virtually. The 2022 draft was held at the Caesars Forum, a conference center located on the Las Vegas Strip.

# Player Selections

The 2022 NFL Draft consisted of seven rounds, with 262 players selected. The first round took place on April 28, while the second and third rounds took place on April 29. The final four rounds took place on April 30. The Jacksonville Jaguars had the first overall pick, which they used to select Travon Walker, a defensive end from the University of Georgia.
